resources.string: On August 21, 2017, a solar eclipse will be visible in North America. People in the narrow path of totality will see the sun\'s disk completely covered by the moon. This app makes it easy to capture images of the eclipse. Your images can also become part of an exciting citizen science project.

Everyone! This app does all the hard work of controlling your smartphone camera to capture images of the eclipse at just the right times. You can use it with just your phone or with an external lens and tripod to get even sharper images of this once-in-a-lifetime event.

The app is very easy to use. You just have to point your phone in the right direction during the eclipse and the app takes the pictures for you. If you have an external lens and tripod, the app will help you set everything up to get the best shots possible.
How do I use the app?

Even a short glance at the sun can cause permanent eye damage. That’s also true during the first and last phases of an eclipse when the sun’s disk is partially covered. So while the dimmer light of a partial eclipse may tempt you, the only time you can safely view the sun is the short period called totality, when the sun is completely covered by the moon.
You are %1$d kilometers from the path of totality.
You are in the path of totality!

About this app 

This app allows you to capture images of the solar eclipse on August 21, 2017. It also lets you share your photos with scientists for a citizen-science project led by the Space Sciences Laboratory and Google. Click here to learn more about the Megamovie Project. The Eclipse Megamovie Mobile app was created by Ideum and the Space Sciences Laboratory at UC Berkeley. 

The app can capture valuable scientific information without additional equipment. But you can obtain even better results with an external lens and tripod. If you already have this equipment or want to learn more, use our built-in Eclipse Orientation Mode to customize the app. 

If you are using an external lens and tripod, the app has a Calibration Mode that will help you focus the lens and point the camera in the right direction. You can practice by capturing images of the moon. 

One outcome of the Megamovie Project will be a movie of the eclipse as it moves across the US. The movie will incorporate high-quality images captured by trained volunteers with DSLR cameras. Once it is available, you can download and view it in the Eclipse Megamovie section.
The Orientation mode helps you determine how best to use the app. \n\nAnswer a few questions on the next screen to optimize your eclipse experience.

The Megamovie Mobile app is designed to help you use your camera phone to take the best possible images of the solar eclipse. It tells you when and where to see the eclipse, how to aim your camera when the eclipse is about to start, and automatically controls your camera’s settings and shutter to take a series of photos during the event. All you’ll have to do is be ready and follow a few simple instructions when the time comes.\n\nThe app also gives you a way to practice before the eclipse so you’ll feel comfortable when the big day arrives—by taking pictures of the moon. Go to Moon-test to try it out.

Holding a camera by hand can cause tiny vibrations that blur photos. This can be especially troublesome with astronomical images. Mounting your phone on a tripod is an easy way to improve your photos. There are many kinds of tripods available for cell phones, including inexpensive ones made by Joby, Square Jellyfish, and Charger City. Also, while your phone may have a great camera, images of the sun are likely to be small unless you use an external lens like those made by Apexel, Hsini, and Neewer. We recommend using a lens with a magnification of at least 20x, although the app is compatible with any lens. Lenses like these are very portable and can help you take great photos of many things in addition to the eclipse. 

Once you’ve decided on the equipment you’ll use, go to My Eclipse to enter your choice (you can change it at any time). 

If you’re using an especially high-powered lens, you might consider using a tracking-mount. A relatively compact and inexpensive choice is the Star Adventurer made by Sky-Watcher.

If you want to use a separate camera to photograph the eclipse, you can still use the eclipse map and countdown functions in the Megamovie Mobile app.
\n\nYou may also be interested in being an official volunteer to capture images for the Megamovie itself. To learn more, visit the Megamovie Website.
This is when the edge of the moon first begins to cover the sun. Even though the sun will start to get dimmer at this point, it’s still not safe to look directly at the eclipse.\n

In a total solar eclipse, this is when totality begins and the sun’s disk is completely covered by the moon. It is safe to remove your eclipse glasses when you can no longer see the bright sun through them. You can now see the sun’s hot, hazy outer atmosphere: the corona! \n

The sun’s corona, a halo of ionized gases, extends millions of miles into space. At over 1 million degrees Fahrenheit, it is much hotter than the sun’s surface. You can only see the whole corona during a total eclipse, such as this one.
Third contact is the moment when totality ends and the sun begins to emerge from the moon’s shadow. As soon as the bright sun appears, you must put your eclipse glasses back on.\n
This is the end of the eclipse.\n

By using the app to capture images of the moon, you\'ll become familiar with how the app works and be ready to use it to photograph the main event: the solar eclipse. \n\nThis will be especially helpful if you will be using an external lens and tripod during the eclipse.
When would you like to start taking pictures of the moon? The app will calculate the location of the moon at that time.

If you don\'t have any extra equipment like a tripod or external lens, you can now enter Capture Mode and the app will take pictures of the moon at the time you selected. \n\nIf you have an external lens, the app can help you focus it correctly. If you are attaching your phone to a tripod, the app can help you point the phone in the right direction.

Turn your phone in the direction of the red line. As you get closer to the correct direction, the blue circle will get larger. The circle will turn green when your phone and tripod are correctly calibrated.

Point the camera at an object that is more than 100 ft away, like a tree or a building (or the moon itself!). Adjust the focus of the external lens until the object in the preview appears crisp and in focus. You may adjust the brightness of the preview using the buttons above.
Align the phone so the moon appears in the center of the red crosshairs. Then press NEXT.
Use the alignment guide below to point the phone towards the predicted location of the moon. Then press FINISH.
If you plan to attach an external lens to your smartphone, you will also need to mount it on a tripod to ensure it is kept steady and pointed in the right direction.

Unfortunately, your phone\'s camera does not support manual control of its sensors, so the app will be unable to capture images of the eclipse. You can still use the other features of the app, however, including the eclipse map and eclipse timing information.

Signing in with your Google Account allows Megamovie Mobile to upload the eclipse images automatically to a server, to be added to the public-domain Megamovie archive. This repository, the first of its kind, will enable scientists and the public to make discoveries about the Moon and about the Sun.

Ideum is a creative company focused on using emerging technologies to design public installations and products that lead to meaningful and compelling user experiences. We work with museums, Fortune 500 companies, and other entities throughout North America and around the world. Our firm provides design services, custom software development, interactive displays, touch tables, and audio-visual (A/V) solutions.

The Space Sciences Laboratory (SSL) is the UC system’s premier space sciences research facility and one of the preeminent university laboratories in the country for space research. Its primary goal is to foster outstanding research in space-related sciences and to provide education for the next generation of space scientists. Research at SSL is led by Berkeley faculty and SSL Senior Fellows, and focuses on experiments and observations carried out in space, but also includes research with the potential of leading to future space experiments, and the theoretical research that is tied into their experimental and observational programs.

Eclipse Across America, Inc. is a non-profit founded by filmmaker/director and eclipse chaser Mark Bender. Its goal is to develop public awareness of the August 21, 2017 total solar eclipse, from the science of how and why eclipses happen, to the different ways scientists, eclipse chasers, and the general public can watch and enjoy this historic event.
